1.title: Week 1: Intro to Microcontrollers
1.description: Hardware, inputs/outputs, MakeCode basics, events & sequencing.

questions.question: Which statement best describes the role of the microcontroller inside a micro:bit?
options: It processes sensor inputs and controls outputs according to your code
It only stores your program in memory
It powers the LEDs and buttons directly without processing
It connects the micro:bit to the internet
questions.explanation: The microcontroller is the 'brain' — it runs your program, reading inputs and sending signals to outputs.
questions.definition: MICROCONTROLLER — a small processor that executes code and manages inputs/outputs in embedded systems.
questions.hint: Think of it as the part that actually runs your code and decides what to do next.

questions.question: Which example shows the micro:bit receiving information from its surroundings?
options: Showing an arrow on the screen
Playing a sound through the speaker
Flashing the LEDs in a pattern
questions.explanation: The accelerometer senses movement — an input from the environment. The other options send information outward, making them outputs.
questions.hint: Ask yourself: is the micro:bit reading or displaying information?

questions.question: In the code below, which block ensures the text appears only one time before the heart starts flashing?
questions.code:
WHEN program starts DO
  SHOW TEXT "Hello!"
FOREVER DO
  SHOW ICON Heart
  PAUSE 500 ms
  CLEAR SCREEN
  PAUSE 500 ms
questions.explanation: Anything inside 'on start' runs just once. The 'forever' loop repeats endlessly, but 'on start' finishes after its commands.
questions.hint: Only one block type is designed for setup instructions that don’t repeat.

questions.question: If you upload this code to the micro:bit, what will you see happen and why?
questions.code:
FOREVER DO
  SHOW TEXT "Hi"
options: It scrolls 'Hi' endlessly because there’s no stop condition
It only shows 'Hi' once because the display clears automatically
It shows 'Hi' five times, matching the number of LEDs
It waits for button A before showing 'Hi'
questions.explanation: Because the text is inside a 'forever' block, it repeats continuously without stopping until the micro:bit is reset or turned off.
questions.hint: Does anything in the code tell it to stop?

questions.question: The LED grid on a micro:bit can both show light and measure light levels. What type of device is it mostly considered?
options: Both input and output, but mainly output
questions.explanation: While the LED matrix can detect light levels, its primary role is to display information — so it’s mainly an output device.
questions.hint: It can sense light but that’s not its main purpose.

questions.question: Match each term to its definition.
questions.explanation: Event triggers code; sequence is order; debug means fix mistakes.
questions.hint: Cause → Event; order → Sequence; fixing → Debug.

questions.question: Where can you test your micro:bit program without using the real device?
options: In the MakeCode simulator on the screen
By opening the MICROBIT drive on your computer
By plugging in the battery pack only
questions.explanation: The MakeCode simulator runs your program virtually and lets you try buttons, shaking and LEDs on screen.
questions.definition: SIMULATOR — a virtual version of the micro:bit you can test inside MakeCode.
questions.hint: Which one shows a working virtual micro:bit on your screen?

questions.question: Which statement about 'on button A pressed' is true?
options: It runs in a loop automatically
It runs only when A is pressed
questions.explanation: Event code runs when the event happens — here, pressing Button A.
questions.hint: It waits for something to happen.

questions.question: What is a program?
options: A set of instructions a computer follows
An image on the LED matrix
questions.explanation: A program is a precise sequence of instructions.
questions.definition: PROGRAM — a precise list of instructions a computer follows.
questions.hint: Think of a recipe for a computer.

questions.question: Why might your program not appear on the micro:bit after download?
questions.explanation: All of these are common causes.
questions.hint: Check the obvious steps and connections.

questions.question: Which example shows input → process → output in the correct order?
questions.explanation: Input (button) → processing/logic → output (display).
questions.hint: First comes data in, then thinking, then feedback out.

questions.question: Which block would you use to run code continuously during the entire program?
questions.explanation: The forever loop keeps running as long as the program runs.
questions.hint: Think of a heartbeat the program always follows.

2.title: Week 2: Events & Random
2.description: Button events, dice rolling, randomness, simple probability.

questions.question: When does the code inside the block 'on button A pressed' actually run?
options: Only when button A is pressed down
questions.explanation: The code runs only when button A is pressed down. Other buttons or automatic timing don’t trigger it.
questions.hint: It listens for one exact action on one button.

questions.question: What does 'random 1 to 6' give you?
questions.explanation: It behaves like a fair six-sided die.
questions.definition: RANDOM — the computer chooses by chance from a range.
questions.hint: Think dice.

questions.question: What is an event in programming?
options: Something that triggers code to run
questions.explanation: Events trigger code when they occur (press, shake, start).
questions.hint: It’s the “when” that makes code start.

questions.question: This dice roller runs when you press Button A. What happens each time you press it?
questions.code:
WHEN button A is pressed DO
  SET roll TO random 1 to 6
  SHOW NUMBER roll
options: It picks a new number from 1 to 6 and shows it
It keeps showing the same number every time
It adds 1 to the previous roll and shows that
It shows all six numbers quickly one after another
questions.explanation: Each button A press sets a new random value between 1 and 6, then displays that single number.
questions.hint: Think about what the 'random 1 to 6' block does on each button press.

questions.question: What is the chance of rolling a 4 on a fair six-sided die?
questions.explanation: Each face has equal probability: 1/6.
questions.hint: How many faces are there?

questions.question: If a die is rolled 60 times, about how many 3s would you expect?
questions.explanation: Expected frequency ≈ total × probability = 60 × 1/6 = 10.
questions.hint: Multiply the number of trials by the chance.

questions.question: Which block lets you react to movement of the micro:bit?
questions.explanation: The accelerometer triggers the shake event.
questions.hint: It’s tied to the accelerometer.

questions.question: Match the event to when it triggers.
questions.explanation: Each event maps to a different trigger; forever has no trigger.
questions.hint: Think: beginning, button, motion, always.

questions.question: What message might the micro:bit show when you press Button A?
questions.code:
WHEN button A is pressed DO
  SET x TO random 1 to 10
  IF x > 5 THEN
    SHOW TEXT "Big"
  ELSE
    SHOW TEXT "Small"
options: It shows 'Big' or 'Small' depending on the random number
It always shows 'Big' because 10 is the largest number
It shows 'Small' because x starts at 0
It shows both 'Big' and 'Small' one after another
questions.explanation: Each time you press A, a random number 1–10 is picked. If that number is greater than 5, 'Big' appears; otherwise 'Small'.
questions.hint: Remember: '>' means greater than.

questions.question: What is shown for this coin flip?
questions.code:
WHEN button B is pressed DO
  SET flip TO random 0 to 1
  IF flip = 0 THEN
    SHOW TEXT "Heads"
  ELSE
    SHOW TEXT "Tails"
questions.explanation: Random 0 to 1 maps perfectly to a fair coin.
questions.hint: Two possible values → two possible messages.

questions.question: When this code runs, you sometimes see two different numbers flash quickly. Why?
questions.code:
WHEN button A is pressed DO
  SHOW NUMBER random 1 to 6
  SHOW NUMBER random 1 to 6
options: Because each call to 'random 1 to 6' generates a new value right away
Because the same random value is shown twice at high speed
Because the micro:bit remembers the first number and repeats it
Because the button is pressed for too long
questions.explanation: Both lines use 'random 1 to 6', so two independent random numbers are shown in quick succession.
questions.hint: Does the code reuse the first random value or call it again?

questions.question: After pressing Button A five times, what number will the micro:bit show, and why?
questions.code:
WHEN program starts DO
  SET count TO 0
WHEN button A is pressed DO
  CHANGE count BY 1
  SHOW NUMBER count
options: 5, because 'count' increases by 1 each time and keeps its value
1, because 'count' resets to 0 on every press
0, because the program only runs 'on start'
questions.explanation: The variable 'count' keeps increasing — 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 — with each press.
questions.hint: Does 'set count to 0' happen each time you press the button?

questions.question: What does the else part of an if–else do?
options: Runs when the if is true
Runs when the if is false
questions.explanation: Else handles the “otherwise” case when the if condition isn’t met.
questions.hint: Think: backup plan.

questions.question: Look at this code. Which symbol is checking if the score is exactly 10?
questions.code:
IF score = 10 THEN
  SHOW TEXT "Winner!"
questions.explanation: The '=' sign checks equality.
questions.hint: It compares, not adds.

questions.question: The micro:bit picks a random number 1 to 3 to play Rock–Paper–Scissors. What must the code do next to decide who wins?
options: Use if–else blocks to compare your choice and the random pick
Use 'show string' to display all three options at once
Add 3 to the random number to get the winner
Wait 1 second before showing a smiley
questions.explanation: After choosing randomly, the program compares both choices using if–else logic.
questions.hint: How does the program decide which move wins?

questions.question: What message appears for x = 7?
questions.code:
WHEN button A is pressed DO
  SET x TO 7
  IF x > 5 THEN
    SHOW TEXT "Big"
  ELSE
    SHOW TEXT "Small"
questions.explanation: 7 > 5 is true, so it shows “Big”.
questions.hint: Is 7 greater than 5?

questions.question: What’s the output if number = 5?
questions.code:
SET number TO 5
IF number < 5 THEN
  SHOW TEXT "Low"
ELSE IF number = 5 THEN
  SHOW TEXT "Equal"
ELSE
  SHOW TEXT "High"
questions.explanation: The second condition matches exactly.
questions.hint: Check the exact equality branch.

questions.question: If a coin is fair, what’s the chance of Heads?
questions.explanation: A fair coin has two equally likely outcomes.
questions.hint: How many equally likely outcomes are there?

questions.question: Which condition correctly checks for a tie?
questions.code:
SET player TO "Rock"
SET computer TO "Rock"
IF ???? THEN
  SHOW TEXT "Tie!"
questions.explanation: A tie occurs when both choices are equal.
questions.hint: Same on both sides.

questions.question: Match the comparison to an example that makes it true.
questions.explanation: Each example satisfies the comparison shown.
questions.hint: Plug in the numbers mentally.

questions.question: What does it show when A is pressed?
questions.code:
WHEN button A is pressed DO
  SET roll TO random 1 to 6
  IF roll = 6 THEN
    SHOW ICON "trophy"
  ELSE
    SHOW NUMBER roll
questions.explanation: It branches on a special case: a roll of 6.
questions.hint: Which value triggers the special icon?

questions.question: What will the display show?
questions.code:
SET a TO 3
SET b TO 7
IF a > b THEN
  SHOW TEXT "A"
ELSE IF a = b THEN
  SHOW TEXT "Equal"
ELSE
  SHOW TEXT "B"
questions.explanation: 3 > 7 is false; 3 = 7 is false; it falls through to “B”.
questions.hint: Compare 3 and 7 in order.

questions.question: Why can’t this ever show "B"?
questions.code:
SET n TO 90
IF n >= 90 THEN
  SHOW TEXT "A"
ELSE IF n >= 90 THEN
  SHOW TEXT "B"
ELSE
  SHOW TEXT "C"
options: Because the second condition repeats the first
questions.explanation: The second branch is unreachable since it duplicates the first condition.
questions.hint: Look for a repeated test.

questions.question: What message appears when the code runs?
questions.code:
SET temp TO 20
SET light TO 30
IF temp >= 18 and light >= 50 THEN
  SHOW TEXT "Go Outside"
ELSE
  SHOW TEXT "Stay In"
questions.explanation: Both conditions must be true; light is too low.
questions.hint: and means both must pass.

4.title: Week 4: Variables & Thresholds
4.description: Storing values, comparing to limits, using sensors (light & temperature).

questions.question: What is a variable used for in MakeCode?
options: To store a value that can change while the program runs
To repeat blocks over and over
To read values from sensors like light or temperature
To play sounds or show icons
questions.explanation: A variable is a named space in memory where the program keeps a value that can change, such as a score or sensor reading.
questions.hint: It’s like a labelled box you can open and replace what’s inside.

questions.question: What does 'change score by 5' do if score was 10?
questions.explanation: It adds 5 to the current value: 10 + 5 = 15.
questions.hint: This operation adds, it doesn’t replace.

questions.question: In a micro:bit program, what does a threshold represent?
options: A limit value that decides when something should happen
The exact sensor reading at the start of the program
A random number between two limits
The highest possible temperature the micro:bit can read
questions.explanation: A threshold is a boundary value used to trigger an action — for example, if light level < 100, turn on a torch.
questions.hint: It’s the line between 'go' and 'stop' conditions.

questions.question: If the classroom light level is 80, what message appears when this code runs?
questions.code:
SET lightlevel TO light level
IF lightLevel < 50 THEN
  SHOW TEXT "Too Dark!"
ELSE
  SHOW TEXT "OK"
questions.explanation: The condition is false when lightLevel = 80, so it shows 'OK'.
questions.hint: Which branch runs when the condition is false?

questions.question: What is health after running?
questions.code:
SET health TO 100
CHANGE health BY -20
SET health TO health * 2
questions.hint: Apply steps in order.

questions.question: Match each variable operation to its effect.
questions.explanation: “set” replaces the value; “change by” adds/subtracts.
questions.hint: Replace vs. add.

questions.question: What will display when temp = 35?
questions.code:
SET temp TO temperature (onboard sensor)
SET threshold TO 30
IF temp > threshold THEN
  SHOW TEXT "Too Hot!"
ELSE
  SHOW TEXT "OK"
questions.explanation: 35 > 30 is true, so it shows 'Too Hot!'.
questions.hint: Compare the numbers directly.

questions.question: Which code correctly stores the current light sensor reading into a variable?
questions.explanation: The command stores the live sensor reading into the variable.
questions.hint: Only one uses the actual light sensor reading.

questions.question: Where does the temperature value come from in micro:bit projects?
questions.explanation: We use the micro:bit’s onboard sensor.
questions.hint: No extra hardware this week.

questions.question: You want your plant monitor to warn only when it’s cold and dark. Which line should fill the blank?
questions.code:
SET temp TO temperature (onboard)
SET light TO light level (onboard)
IF __________ THEN
  SHOW TEXT "Cold & Dark"
questions.explanation: and requires both conditions to be true.
questions.hint: Which condition checks that both sensors are below their limits?

questions.question: What’s the logic mistake?
questions.code:
SET temp TO temperature
IF temp > 30 and temp > 40 THEN
  SHOW TEXT "Hot!"
ELSE
  SHOW TEXT "OK"
options: The first comparison is redundant; effectively temp > 40
questions.explanation: If both conditions are '>', the larger threshold dominates.
questions.hint: Which comparison is stricter?

questions.question: What does the code display?
questions.code:
SET points TO 10
CHANGE points BY 15
SET points TO points * 2
SHOW NUMBER points
questions.hint: Follow each step carefully.

5.title: Week 5: Loops & First Game
5.description: Repeat/for/while/forever loops; timing (millis); sprites and simple game logic.

questions.question: What does a FOREVER loop do?
options: Runs a fixed number of times
questions.explanation: It repeats as long as the program is active.
questions.hint: Think: the main heartbeat of a game.

questions.question: What does 'repeat 3 times' do?
options: Runs until a condition is met
questions.explanation: It iterates a fixed number of times.
questions.hint: Count the passes.

questions.question: What is an ITERATION?
questions.explanation: Each cycle of a loop is an iteration.
questions.hint: Imagine stepping through a dance routine once.

questions.question: What will this code make the micro:bit do?
questions.code:
FOREVER DO
  REPEAT 5 TIMES
    SHOW ICON "heart"
    PAUSE 200 ms
    SHOW ICON "small heart"
    PAUSE 200 ms
  CLEAR SCREEN
  PAUSE 800 ms
options: Show one heart that never changes
Show five heartbeats, then pause briefly, repeating forever
Show a random sequence of icons
Show five hearts once and then stop
questions.explanation: The inner 'repeat 5' loop creates five quick heartbeats; the outer 'forever' repeats the pattern.
questions.hint: Think about how the inner loop runs inside the forever loop.

questions.question: What numbers will be shown?
questions.code:
SET counter TO 1
REPEAT 5 TIMES
  SHOW NUMBER counter
  CHANGE counter BY 1
  PAUSE 500 ms
questions.explanation: It starts at 1 and increments after each display.
questions.hint: Check the starting value.

questions.question: What does using 'millis' (elapsed ms) help with?
options: Measuring time between actions for smooth speed control
questions.explanation: millis/elapsed time lets you time updates precisely (e.g., speed).
questions.hint: Think: timers and intervals.

questions.question: What movement happens on the LED screen?
questions.code:
SET sprite TO create sprite at x 0 y 2
REPEAT 4 TIMES
  change sprite x by 1
  PAUSE 150 ms
questions.explanation: Changing x by +1 four times moves it 4 columns to the right.
questions.hint: Positive x goes right; negative x goes left.

questions.question: Match each loop type to what it does in a program.
definitions: Repeats as long as a test remains true
Keeps running endlessly while the program is active
Steps through numbers in order, useful for counting or indexing
Repeats a specific number of times, then stops
questions.explanation: ‘forever’ never ends; ‘repeat N times’ stops after a set count; ‘while’ repeats while a test stays true; ‘for index’ steps through a counting range.
questions.hint: Think: condition / endless / counting / fixed.

questions.question: How many times will it run?
questions.code:
SET c TO 10
WHILE c > 5 DO
  SHOW NUMBER c
  CHANGE c BY -2
questions.explanation: c takes values 10, 8, 6 then stops (3 passes).
questions.hint: Track c step by step.

questions.question: This loop is part of a game timer. What happens when the code runs?
questions.code:
SET counter TO 9
WHILE counter > 0 DO
    IF counter < 0 THEN
        CHANGE counter BY -1
    PAUSE 100 ms
questions.explanation: Inside the loop, counter never changes because counter < 0 is never true. It stays 9, so counter > 0 is always true and the while-loop never ends.
questions.hint: Does the if condition ever become true?

questions.question: What is printed at the end?
questions.code:
SET s TO 0
FOR I FROM 1 TO 4
  CHANGE s BY i
SHOW NUMBER s
questions.hint: Add the range 1..4.

questions.question: What pattern of beeps will you hear?
questions.code:
SET wait TO 600
REPEAT 3 TIMES
  play tone C
  pause wait
  CHANGE wait BY -200
questions.explanation: The pause shrinks each iteration, so beeps come quicker.
questions.hint: Watch the pause value change.

6.title: Week 6: Core Mechanics — Loops, Logic, Timing & Coordinates
6.description: Loops, variables, timing, coordinates, and debugging.

questions.question: A loop updates a sprite once per iteration and then pauses for 80 ms. Approximately how many updates happen in 2 seconds?
questions.explanation: 2,000 ms / 80 ms ≈ 25 iterations (rounding down).
questions.hint: Convert seconds to milliseconds first.

questions.question: A sprite starts at x = 2 on the bottom row of the LED grid. The code runs three times. Where will the sprite end up?
questions.code:
SET x TO 2
REPEAT 3 TIMES
  IF x > 0 then change x by -1 THEN
END
options: One step left of the start position
questions.explanation: Each loop step moves the sprite one space left while x > 0. After two moves it reaches x = 0, and the last if does nothing because x is no longer greater than 0.
questions.hint: Imagine the sprite moving left one step each loop until it reaches the edge.

questions.question: A program increments the score when an event occurs. It begins with score = 3 and speed = 200 ms. The event happens 7 times; each time the score increments by 1 and the speed decreases by 10. What are the final values?
questions.explanation: Increment means increase — the score goes from 3 up to 10 (3 + 7 = 10). Each time the event happens, speed goes down by 10, so 200 − 70 = 130 ms.
questions.hint: Increment means 'increase by' — think about how both values change each event.

questions.question: Look at this game loop. What happens when the sprite touches an obstacle?
questions.code:
FOREVER DO
  move sprite by 1
  IF sprite is touching obstacle THEN
    game over
  SHOW NUMBER score
options: The score shows one more time after game over
The game stops immediately after game over, so anything after that line doesn’t run
The loop restarts from the top after game over
questions.explanation: In MakeCode, 'game over' ends the program. Any code after it — even in the same loop — will not run.
questions.hint: When the game ends, does the micro:bit still keep running the forever loop?

questions.question: A micro:bit should play an alarm only if it’s dark and Button A is pressed. When will the sound play?
questions.code:
IF light < 50 and button A is pressed THEN
    play sound 'alarm'
ELSE
    stop all sounds
options: Only when it’s dark and Button A is pressed
Whenever it’s dark, even if Button A isn’t pressed
Whenever Button A is pressed, no matter the light
It never plays because the light test comes first
questions.explanation: Both conditions must be true at the same time — dark and button pressed — for the alarm to play. The 'and' block joins two tests together.
questions.hint: Both parts of the 'and' must be true together.

questions.question: What is the value of c after the loop finishes?
questions.code:
SET c TO 1
REPEAT 5 TIMES
  CHANGE c BY 2
END
questions.explanation: c increases by 2 five times: 1 + 10 = 11.
questions.hint: Repeated addition.

questions.question: About how many times does count increase during ~1 second of running?
questions.code:
SET count TO 0
SET start TO millis()
WHILE millis() < start + 1000 DO
  CHANGE count BY 1
  pause (50)
END
questions.explanation: ≈ 1000/50 = 20 increments (ignoring small overheads).
questions.hint: Divide total time by pause time.

questions.question: How many times does 'plot' run on a 5×5 LED grid?
questions.code:
for x from 0 to 4
  for y from 0 to 4
    plot (x, y)
  end
end
questions.explanation: 5×5 = 25 total iterations.
questions.hint: Multiply the sizes of both ranges.

questions.question: After the loop, what are x and dir?
questions.code:
SET x TO 2
SET dir TO +1
REPEAT 6 TIMES
  IF x = 4 then set dir = -1 THEN
  IF x = 0 then set dir = +1 THEN
  CHANGE x BY dir
END
questions.explanation: Trace: 2→3→4 (flip next)→3→2→1→0; after 6 steps, x = 0 and dir is -1 (flip would occur next).
questions.hint: Check when dir flips: before or after moving?

questions.question: Why does the score remain 0?
questions.code:
SET score TO 0
FOREVER DO
  IF event then change score by 1 THEN
  SET score TO 0
END
options: The score is reset to 0 every loop iteration
Variables cannot be changed inside forever
The change block only works once
questions.explanation: The reset happens on every pass, wiping any increment.
questions.hint: Look at where 'set score = 0' is placed.

questions.question: A sprite starts at x = 1 on the bottom row of the micro:bit screen. The code below runs twice. Where does the sprite end up?
questions.code:
SET x TO 1
REPEAT 2 TIMES
  IF x < 3 then change x by 2 else change x by -1 THEN
END
questions.explanation: First loop: 1 < 3 so x becomes 3. Second loop: 3 < 3 is false, so x changes by −1 and becomes 2. Final x = 2.
questions.hint: Follow each step: check the condition, then change x accordingly.

questions.question: A sprite moves across the screen in a forever loop. Where should the 'change score by 1' block go if you want the score to increase every time the sprite reaches the edge?
options: Inside the loop, after checking if sprite is touching the edge
At the very top of the loop, before any checks
Outside the loop, after the forever block
Anywhere in the code — it doesn’t matter
questions.explanation: You need to check the edge first, then increase the score inside the loop when that condition is true. Code outside the loop only runs once at the start.
questions.hint: Forever loops repeat actions — things outside them happen only once.

7.title: Week 7: Functions, Variables, Loops, Conditions & Sensors
7.description: Functions as reusable helpers, accelerometer, loop/timing maths, pseudocode tracing.

questions.question: Why do programmers use functions when making programs?
options: To store numbers like score or speed
To reuse the same set of steps without rebuilding them each time
To keep the program running forever
questions.explanation: Functions let you reuse the same instructions instead of repeating code, which makes programs easier to change later.
questions.definition: FUNCTION — a named mini-program that does one clear job; you call it when you need it.
questions.hint: Think: reuse the same instructions instead of repeating them.

questions.question: What number is shown at the end?
questions.code:
FUNCTION bumpLevel()
    CHANGE level BY 1
END FUNCTION

SET level TO 2
REPEAT 2 TIMES
    CALL bumpLevel()
END
SHOW NUMBER level
questions.explanation: level: 2 → 3 → 4, then displayed.
questions.hint: The helper runs twice.

questions.question: A sprite moves left or right based on tilt. Starting at x = 2, after readings 350, 100, −260, what is x? (Move right if X > +200; left if X < −200; otherwise no move.)
questions.code:
SET x TO 2
REPEAT 3 TIMES
    IF acceleration (X) > 200 THEN
        CHANGE x BY 1
    ELSE IF acceleration (X) < -200 THEN
        CHANGE x BY -1
    END IF
END
SHOW NUMBER x
questions.hint: Only big tilts (>|200|) move the sprite.

questions.question: Which branch runs for a right tilt (X = +400)?
questions.code:
IF acceleration (X) > 200 THEN
    move sprite right
ELSE IF acceleration (X) < -200 THEN
    move sprite left
END IF
questions.explanation: Positive X over the threshold triggers the first branch.
questions.hint: Positive = right.

questions.question: Speed (ms) gets smaller by 20 each score but can’t go below 80 ms. Starting at 180 ms, what is speed after 6 scores?
questions.code:
SET speed TO 180
REPEAT 6 TIMES
    CHANGE speed BY -20
    IF speed < 80 THEN
        SET speed TO 80
    END IF
END
SHOW NUMBER speed
questions.hint: Stop at the minimum.

questions.question: The level is worked out as: level = 1 + (score ÷ 4) using whole-number division. What is the smallest score that gives level = 3?
questions.code:
SET level TO 1
# level = 1 + (score ÷ 4)   // ÷ is integer division
# Choose the smallest score that makes level become 3
questions.explanation: At score 8: 8 ÷ 4 = 2, so level = 1 + 2 = 3. At 7 it’s still 2.
questions.hint: Divide by 4 (no decimals), then add 1.

questions.question: What number is shown at the end?
questions.code:
SET score TO 0
FUNCTION addPoint()
    CHANGE score BY 1
END FUNCTION

REPEAT 3 TIMES
    CALL addPoint()
END
SHOW NUMBER score
questions.explanation: addPoint runs three times → score = 3.
questions.hint: Count the calls.

questions.question: Total pause time (ms) for the whole program?
questions.code:
FUNCTION blink(times, ms)
    repeat times times
        SHOW ICON "heart"
        pause ms
        CLEAR SCREEN
        pause ms
    end repeat
END FUNCTION

REPEAT 3 TIMES
    CALL blink(2, 150)
END
questions.explanation: One call: 2 × (150+150) = 600 ms. Three calls → 1800 ms.
questions.hint: Each blink cycle has two pauses.

questions.question: What message appears on the screen?
questions.code:
SET temp TO 18
IF temp > 30 THEN
    SHOW TEXT "Hot"
ELSE IF temp < 18 THEN
    SHOW TEXT "Cold"
ELSE
    SHOW TEXT "OK"
END IF
questions.explanation: At exactly 18, neither >30 nor <18 is true → “OK”.
questions.hint: Mind the strict > and <.

questions.question: Which block fits the blank so this runs three times after A is pressed (and not forever)?
questions.code:
WHEN button A is pressed DO
    ______
        move sprite by 1
        PAUSE 150 ms
    END
questions.explanation: “repeat 3 times” limits the action to exactly three moves per press.
questions.hint: Look for a fixed-count loop.

questions.question: Starting at x = 1, the sprite moves when the tilt is big. Readings: 250, 250, −300. Rule: if X > +200 move right (+1); if X < −200 move left (−1); otherwise no move. What number is shown?
questions.code:
SET x TO 1
FOR EACH reading IN [250, 250, -300] DO
    IF acceleration (X) > 200 THEN
        CHANGE x BY 1
    ELSE IF acceleration (X) < -200 THEN
        CHANGE x BY -1
    END IF
END
SHOW NUMBER x
questions.hint: Only move on big tilts.

questions.question: Why does the sprite move even when the button isn’t pressed?
questions.code:
FOREVER DO
    move sprite by 1
    IF button A is pressed THEN
        PAUSE 200 ms
    END IF
END
options: The pause should be outside the forever loop
The move should be inside the if statement
The button A block is incorrect
questions.explanation: The movement isn’t inside the condition, so it runs every loop. The `move` block should be placed inside the `if` statement.
questions.hint: Look carefully at what’s *inside* vs *outside* the if block.

8.title: Week 8: Waves, Radio & Logic Review
8.description: Wave science, event logic, functions, counters, timing, thresholds, and coordinates.

questions.question: Pseudocode — what icon is finally on screen?
questions.code:
SET hasmsg TO false
SHOW ICON "Duck"
WHEN message received (n) DO
    IF n = myID THEN
        SET hasmsg TO true
    END IF
END
IF hasMsg THEN
    SHOW ICON "Ghost"
END
options: It flashes both quickly, ending blank
questions.explanation: The final if runs immediately (still false), so the Duck remains. Only a later matching message would switch to Ghost.
questions.hint: Does any matching message arrive before the final check?

questions.question: Match the radio/wave term to its description.
definitions: How many waves happen each second
questions.explanation: Amplitude = height; Frequency = per-second count; Wavelength = spacing; Receiver = listens.
questions.hint: Label a sketched wave first, then place the device.

questions.question: Pseudocode — how many readings count as “dark”? (threshold < 60)
questions.code:
SET dark TO 0
SET readings TO [61, 59, 20, 60, 58, 99]
FOR EACH r IN readings DO
    IF r < 60 THEN
        CHANGE dark BY 1
    END IF
END
SHOW NUMBER dark
questions.hint: Watch strictly less than: 60 itself does not count.

questions.question: A message is received with number = myID. What will the micro:bit show?
questions.code:
WHEN message received (n) DO
    IF n = myID THEN
        SHOW TEXT "OK"
    ELSE
        SHOW TEXT "NO"
    END IF
END
# One message arrives where n = myID
options: It shows both OK then NO
questions.explanation: Because the message number equals myID, the first condition is true, so it shows 'OK'.
questions.hint: Check which branch runs when the test is true.

questions.question: How long (in milliseconds) does this whole sequence take?
questions.code:
FOR I FROM 1 TO 6   # I INCREASES BY 1 EACH TIME
    PAUSE 100 ms
    IF i is even THEN
        PAUSE 50 ms
    END IF
END
questions.explanation: Each loop always pauses 100 ms → 6×100 = 600. On loops 2, 4, and 6 (even numbers), it adds another 50 ms each → +150. Total = 750 ms.
questions.hint: Even-numbered loops take slightly longer.

questions.question: Match to Input/Output/Variable role.
questions.explanation: Accelerometer reads movement (input); scrolling text is an output; score is stored in a variable.
questions.hint: Read the world, tell the world, remember a value.

questions.question: Coordinates — what x is finally shown?
questions.code:
SET x TO 2
CHANGE x BY 3
IF x > 4 then set x = 4 THEN
CHANGE x BY -1
IF x < 0 then set x = 0 THEN
SHOW NUMBER x
questions.explanation: Start 2 → +3 = 5 → clamp to 4 → -1 = 3 → still ≥ 0 → show 3.
questions.hint: Clamp to the grid (0..4) before the next move.

questions.question: Radio group & ID — how many times does score increase after messages arrive in order: [1, 2, 3, 2, 1]?
questions.code:
SET myid TO 2
SET score TO 0
WHEN message received (n) DO
    IF n = myID then change score by 1 THEN
END
questions.explanation: Only messages equal to 2 count → positions 2 and 4 → score +2.
questions.hint: Count only exact matches.

questions.question: Find the logic bug — which statement is correct?
questions.code:
SET temp TO 35
IF temp > 30 THEN
    show "Hot"
ELSE IF temp > 34 THEN
    show "Very Hot"
ELSE
    show "OK"
END IF
options: Nothing shows because both conditions are wrong
"Hot" will show because the first true test runs and the rest are skipped
"OK" will show because 35 is not greater than 34
questions.explanation: The first branch (temp > 30) is true, so the later, stricter test is never reached.
questions.hint: Order of tests matters; first match wins.

questions.question: Counter inside a loop — what is shown?
questions.code:
SET c TO 0
REPEAT 4 TIMES
    CHANGE c BY 2
    IF c > 3 then set c = 1 THEN
END
SHOW NUMBER c
questions.explanation: Follow c step by step: start 0 → loop 1: c = 2 → loop 2: c becomes 4, then resets to 1 → loop 3: c becomes 3 (no reset) → loop 4: c becomes 5, then resets to 1. Final c = 1.
questions.hint: Apply the reset each time c passes 3.

questions.question: Functions & parameters — what number shows?
questions.code:
FUNCTION addTwice(a, b)
    RETURN a + a + b
END FUNCTION
SET x TO 3
SET y TO 4
SHOW NUMBER addTwice(y, x)
questions.explanation: Here a = y = 4 and b = x = 3, so a + a + b = 4 + 4 + 3 = 11.
questions.hint: Mind which argument is ‘a’ and which is ‘b’.

questions.question: Match the CS idea to a clear example.
definitions: Run steps in order: A then B then C
Store a value like score that can change
Choose a branch based on a test
questions.explanation: Sequence = ordered steps; Selection = choose by condition; Repetition = loop; Variable = stored value.
questions.hint: Think: order, choice, repeat, remember.

9.title: Week 9: Fireflies, Radio & Local Rules
9.description: Synchronisation and local communication, radio groups, message logic, plus revision of events, variables, loops, timing, and coordinates.

questions.question: Why is it important that devices use the same radio group number when communicating?
options: It lets them send stronger messages
Only devices on the same group can hear each other's messages
questions.explanation: Radio groups act like channels. Devices must match the group number to receive each other's messages.
questions.hint: Think: like walkie-talkie channels.

questions.question: Pseudocode — how many times does the loop run?
questions.code:
SET clock TO 0
repeat until clock >= 6
    PAUSE 100 ms
    CHANGE clock BY 1
END
questions.explanation: clock starts at 0. Each loop adds 1. It stops when clock becomes 6, so it runs exactly 6 times.
questions.hint: Trace clock: 0,1,2,3,4,5,6.

questions.question: Match each concept to the best description.
definitions: A small instruction each device follows on its own
Devices gradually lining up their timing without a leader
A shared channel number that devices agree to use
A packet of data sent from one device to another
questions.explanation: Synchronisation is lining up timing; a local rule is the small behaviour each device follows; a radio group is the shared channel; a message is the data packet sent.
questions.hint: Think: behaviour, overall pattern, channel, and data.

questions.question: Pseudocode — how many times does score increase?
questions.code:
SET myid TO 4
SET score TO 0
SET received TO [2, 4, 4, 3, 4]
FOR EACH n IN received DO
    IF n = myID THEN
        CHANGE score BY 1
    END IF
END
SHOW NUMBER score
questions.explanation: The value 4 appears three times in the list, so score increases three times → final score = 3.
questions.hint: Count only the messages where n equals 4.

questions.question: True or False: Two micro:bits on different radio groups can still receive each other’s messages if they are close together.
questions.explanation: Radio groups behave like separate channels. Devices must share the same group number to receive each other’s messages.
questions.hint: Think of groups like different walkie-talkie channels.

questions.question: Pseudocode — what number is finally shown?
questions.code:
SET x TO 1
REPEAT 4 TIMES
    CHANGE x BY 2
END
SHOW NUMBER x
questions.explanation: x starts at 1. It increases by 2 four times: 1 → 3 → 5 → 7 → 9. The final value is 9.
questions.hint: Add 2 each time, four times in total.

questions.question: Pseudocode — what is the final value of counter?
questions.code:
SET counter TO 0
SET readings TO [70, 45, 30, 60]
FOR EACH r IN readings DO
    IF r < 60 THEN
        CHANGE counter BY 1
    END IF
END
SHOW NUMBER counter
questions.explanation: Values less than 60 are 45 and 30 → 2 increments. (70 and 60 are not counted.)
questions.hint: Only count readings where r < 60.

questions.question: Which situation is a good example of local communication in a system?
options: Every device asks a central server for instructions every second
Each device only listens to, receives and sends information to nearby devices
One device sends a command directly to every other device in the room
All devices share one global variable stored on the internet
questions.explanation: Local communication means reacting to nearby signals rather than taking orders from a single controller.
questions.hint: Local = neighbours, not bosses.

questions.question: Match the code idea to what it controls.
definitions: Decides which branch of code will run
Stores a value like a score or sensor reading
Repeats a set of instructions again and again
Starts running code when something happens
questions.explanation: Event → starts code; Loop → repeats code; Variable → stores a changeable value; Condition → decides which branch runs.
questions.hint: Think: when / repeat / remember / choose.

questions.question: Pseudocode — which condition will never run because of the order of the tests?
questions.code:
SET temp TO 28
IF temp > 25 THEN
    show "Hot"
ELSE IF temp > 20 THEN
    show "Warm"
ELSE IF temp > 10 THEN
    show "Mild"
ELSE
    show "Cold"
END IF
options: None — all of them can run in some situation
questions.explanation: All three conditions can be true for different values of temp (for example: 30 → Hot, 22 → Warm, 15 → Mild). None of the branches are unreachable.
questions.hint: Think about what happens for different values: 30, 22, 15, and 5.

questions.question: Pseudocode — what number will be shown?
questions.code:
SET level TO 1
SET score TO 7
IF score >= 10 THEN
    SET level TO 3
ELSE IF score >= 5 THEN
    SET level TO 2
END IF
SHOW NUMBER level
questions.explanation: score = 7 is not >= 10, but it is >= 5, so level becomes 2.
questions.hint: The tests are checked in order; the first true one wins.

questions.question: Pseudocode — where does the sprite finish on the x-axis?
questions.code:
SET x TO 2
REPEAT 3 TIMES
    IF x < 4 THEN
        CHANGE x BY 1
    ELSE
        CHANGE x BY -1
    END IF
END
SHOW NUMBER x
questions.explanation: Step 1: x=2<4 → x=3. Step 2: 3<4 → x=4. Step 3: 4<4 is false → x=3. Final x = 3.
questions.hint: Trace x carefully for each repeat.

10.title: Week 10: Arrays and Iteration
10.description: Arrays, loops, counters, conditions and earlier concepts.

questions.question: What does an index represent in an array?
options: The number of elements the array can hold
The position of an element inside the array
The value stored at the first element
A special variable used only in loops
questions.explanation: An index is the position of an element in an array. Indexing starts at 0.

questions.question: An array contains 5 elements. Which of these is a valid index?
questions.explanation: A 5-element array has valid positions 0, 1, 2, 3 and 4.

questions.question: Which description best explains why arrays are useful?
options: They store many related values inside one variable and let loops process them.
They make programs faster even without loops.
They generate random numbers without using the random block.
questions.explanation: Arrays group related values so loops can process or check them efficiently.

questions.question: Pseudocode — what numbers are shown on the micro:bit?
questions.code:
SET nums TO [9, 3, 6, 12]
FOR EACH value IN nums DO
    SHOW NUMBER (value divided by 3)
END
questions.explanation: Each array element is divided by 3.
questions.hint: Follow each element in order: 3 then 6 then 9 then 12.

questions.question: Which line correctly checks if an array is empty?
questions.explanation: An array is empty when its length (number of elements) is 0.

questions.question: Pseudocode — what does this loop do?
questions.code:
FOR EACH item IN arr DO
    do something
END
options: Repeats a random number of times
Repeats once for every element stored in the array
Repeats until the array becomes empty
Repeats only for the first element
questions.explanation: The loop runs once per element in the array arr.

questions.question: Pseudocode — what number is finally shown?
questions.code:
SET score TO 0
FOR I FROM 0 TO 4   # I INCREASES BY 1 EACH TIME
    IF (i remainder of 2) = 0 THEN
        CHANGE score BY 1
    END IF
END
SHOW NUMBER score
questions.explanation: i takes values 0, 1, 2, 3, 4. Even numbers have remainder 0 when divided by 2. The even values are 0, 2 and 4 → score increases 3 times.
questions.hint: Count how many even values appear between 0 and 4.

questions.question: Missing line — choose the line that correctly picks a random activity from an array.
questions.code:
SET activities TO ["read", "run", "draw"]
pick random index from 0 to 2
____
SHOW TEXT chosen
questions.explanation: We need to read the element at that index: chosen = activities[index].
questions.hint: We want to copy one element out of the array into chosen.

questions.question: Missing line — this loop removes low readings from the front of an array. Which condition fits in the blank?
questions.code:
SET readings TO [12, 30, 55, 80, 10]
SET threshold TO 50
WHILE length of readings > 0 and ____ DO
    remove first element from readings
END
questions.explanation: We want to keep removing values from the front while they are below the threshold. The correct condition is: first element < threshold.
questions.hint: Think about when the loop should stop removing values.

questions.question: Pseudocode — what does the array numbers contain at the end?
questions.code:
SET numbers TO []
FOR I FROM 1 TO 4
    add i*i to numbers
END
questions.explanation: For i = 1,2,3,4 we add 1,4,9,16 to the array.
questions.hint: i*i means i multiplied by itself.

questions.question: Which statement about arrays is correct?
options: An array can only store numbers.
Arrays can store only data of the same type.
Arrays cannot be used inside loops.
questions.explanation: In MakeCode, arrays must store values of one type (all numbers, all strings, etc.), even though some languages allow mixed types.

questions.question: Pseudocode — what number is shown?
questions.code:
SET arr TO [2, 4, 6]
SET total TO 0
FOR EACH n IN arr DO
    CHANGE total BY n
END
SHOW NUMBER total
questions.explanation: We add 2 + 4 + 6, giving a total of 12.

11.title: Week 11: Ultrasonic Sensors & Mapping
11.description: Ultrasonic distance sensing, mapping and constrain, plus recap of variables, comparisons and loops.

questions.question: What does an ultrasonic sensor measure?
options: Brightness of light in the area
How fast the micro:bit is shaking
questions.explanation: An ultrasonic sensor measures how long a sound pulse takes to go out, bounce off an object, and come back. From that time, the program can calculate distance.
questions.hint: Think of how bats use sound to locate things in the dark.

questions.question: In pseudocode, what does this line do: SET delay TO map(distance, 10, 200, 100, 800)?
options: It copies distance into delay without changing it
It adds 100 to the distance value
It checks whether distance is between 100 and 800
It converts the distance range into a new range of delay values
questions.explanation: map(distance, 10, 200, 100, 800) takes a value in the range 10–200 and finds its matching position in the new range 100–800. The shape (proportion) stays the same, the numbers change.
questions.hint: Think about changing from one range of values to another, like 0–100 into 0–4.

questions.question: Which statement about constrain(x, a, b) is true?
options: It keeps x between a and b by limiting it to that range
It randomly changes x on every loop
It only works if x is negative
It makes x increase by 1 each time
questions.explanation: constrain(x, a, b) forces the value x to stay inside the limits a and b. If x is smaller than a, it becomes a; if x is larger than b, it becomes b; otherwise it stays the same.
questions.hint: Imagine squeezing a value so it cannot go below the minimum or above the maximum.

questions.question: Choose the line that correctly checks if a distance reading is too close.
questions.code:
SET d TO sensor_reading
IF ______ THEN
    SHOW TEXT "Close!"
END IF
questions.explanation: The test d < 20 becomes true when the distance is less than 20 units (for example, centimetres), which is a good way to flag that something is very near.
questions.hint: Which condition means “nearer than a limit” rather than “bigger than a limit”?

questions.question: Why is dividing the echo time by 58 commonly used in ultrasonic distance formulas?
options: 58 is just a random number chosen for convenience
It represents the number of LEDs on the micro:bit
It converts the echo time from microseconds into centimetres for the distance
It slows down the program so humans can read the values
questions.explanation: Sound travels at about 340 m/s (about 0.034 cm per microsecond). Because the pulse goes out and back, the distance calculation uses a constant that is approximately 58 to convert round-trip time to one-way distance in centimetres.
questions.hint: Think physics: speed of sound, time and distance are linked.

questions.question: Match each term to what it does.
questions.explanation: Mapping converts a value from one range into a matching value in another range; constrain keeps a value inside a minimum and maximum; a variable stores a value that can change; a sensor reads data from the world.
questions.hint: Think: who senses, who remembers, who squeezes values, who rescales them.

questions.question: Pseudocode — what number is shown on the display?
questions.code:
SET x TO 5
SET y TO map(x, 0, 10, 0, 100)
SHOW NUMBER y
questions.explanation: x = 5 is exactly halfway between 0 and 10, so its mapped value y is halfway between 0 and 100, which is 50.
questions.hint: Mapping keeps the position in the range the same (middle maps to middle).

questions.question: Pseudocode — after constraining, what is the value of s?
questions.code:
SET s TO 250
SET s TO constrain(s, 0, 200)
SHOW NUMBER s
questions.explanation: The value 250 is above the upper limit of 200, so constrain changes s to 200. It cannot go higher than the maximum.
questions.hint: If a value is above the maximum limit, it is clipped down to that limit.

questions.question: Which line correctly reads a sensor distance value into the variable distance before checking it?
questions.code:
_____
IF distance < 40 THEN
    SHOW ICON "skull"
END IF
questions.explanation: We want to copy the latest reading from the sensor into the variable distance, so we can use it in the IF test. SET distance TO sensor_reading does exactly that.
questions.hint: Which line copies data from the sensor into the variable we are testing?

questions.question: A program maps distance to LED brightness. Why is mapping needed here?
options: Because the LED grid only accepts values from 0 to 9
Because mapping automatically plays sound at the same time
Because brightness uses a different value range than distance
Because mapping prevents the program from crashing
questions.explanation: Distance is usually measured in centimetres, while LED brightness uses a range like 0–255. Mapping scales the distance values into a range that the brightness setting can use.
questions.hint: Think about how a value measured in centimetres can be turned into a brightness level.

questions.question: Match each comparison to a value that makes it true.
questions.explanation: 60 is greater than 50; 3 is less than 10; 30 equals 30; 10 is a value that is not 20.
questions.hint: Mentally plug each value into the comparison and see if it makes the statement true.

questions.question: Pseudocode — how many increments happen in total?
questions.code:
SET count TO 0
SET readings TO [5, 18, 22, 8, 40]
FOR EACH r IN readings DO
    IF r < 20 THEN
        CHANGE count BY 1
    END IF
END
SHOW NUMBER count
questions.explanation: Values less than 20 are 5, 18 and 8. That makes three increments of count, so the final value shown is 3.
questions.hint: Only count readings that are strictly smaller than 20, not equal to 20.
